author: Ciantic
body:
Suppose I have devised some magical command line, e.g.
gci -recurse *.php | select name, Directory, LastWriteTime | sort lastwritetime

And now I have list of files and paths in front of me, it would be useful to be able to click or ctrl+click on the powershell window to open the path in file explorer. 

Open question is how it should behave if I ctrl click a file path (vs. directory path) should it give options to open the file or browse to the path?

I think command Ctrl+Click is somewhat defacto e.g. for URLs in other programs like nutty etc.

Thanks for considering.

comments.author: joeyaiello
comments.body:
I'm not *positive* on this,, but I believe this would require changes to the console host before PowerShell could do anything.  

In fact, it looks like there's already a UserVoice suggestion for the Windows conhost: https://wpdev.uservoice.com/forums/266908-command-prompt-console-bash-on-ubuntu-on-windo/suggestions/6511299-make-links-clickable

Feel free to upvote that one!

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I would even say that it is not a powershell and conhost function, it is rather VT and operating system function similar to launch default applications in cmd.exe.

comments.author: Ciantic
comments.body: I'm closing this since the uservoice voting addresses this already.

comments.author: lzybkr
comments.body:
Console applications like PowerShell can implement features like this (process mouse input) but very few do these days.

That said, this feature makes sense for conhost to support as that helps all console applications.

title: Feature: powershell.exe mouse clickable file paths
